p.s: In order to underline his critical view on the current language-learninglanguage learning situation in the UK, John Worne implies a variety of communicative strategies and a concrete use of language which makes his opinion more convincing.
Looking at the language the author is using, it can be said that he refers to ana rather educated readership, but still in a way that his opinion is understandable for non-experts.
Often he makes use of a complex syntax (ll. 3-5) and a sophisticated vocabulary (l. 5).
Through that he creates more validy, which also underlines his point of the need of a better knowledge of language in the UK.
On the other hand, he also uses words like Cobblers(l. 15), which are rather informal.
With that he also includes a not too educated readership.
Furthermore he adresses his readers directly in lines 12 till 14lines 12 till 14(you) and in line 32: So, parents of the UK, which means that in general this article is meant to be read by parents.
Worne also points out, that he himself is a parent with first person pronoun I(l. 32), which creates more authenticity through the illusion that he seems to know what he is talking about.
To underline that even more, he makes use of the inclusive pronouns we(l. 33), our(l. 34) and us(l. 35).
That creates a feeling of a community of himself and the readership which has to take care of the issue the author describes.
To underline that issue even more, Worne also implies stilisticstylistic devices.
In the last paragraph he uses the metaphorametaphor, which describes languages and international experiences as essential strings to our [the readership's] children's bows.
Through that the author emphasizes how essential languages are for the young people in order to be successful.

He also illustrates how important languageskillslanguage skills are with the comparison in lines 27 till 29, where he gives an example of a lawyer with a variety of language skills in contrast to one who cannot speak more than one language.
Through that he makes clear, how important the learning of language is for many different jobs.
Another very popular argumentative strategy in the given article is the use of many different data, numbers and statistics (ll. 9-10, l. 8).
For example by refereningreferencing historical developments and data in lines 9 till 10 he creates validyvalidity, which makes his opinion more convincing.

The fact that he does not use any quotes mabe could lower his validyvalidity, but on the other hand it also creates the effect, that the reader sees the author as an expert, who does not need any more experts in order to make ishis point.
Another striking stylistic device can be found in the headline, where he uses the enumeration 'can't, won't, don't', which he then also repeats at the beginning of his article (l. 1).
By doing that, he catches the readership and illustrates the issue, that the students in the UK can't speak the langugeslanguages and won't / don't learn it.
The author also armes with an argumentative structure, which emphasizes his point of view.

For example in lines 12 till 15 he explains the arguments that his own opinion and then makes them weak, by describing it as nonsense (l. 15), which geives the illusion to the reader, that the author's point of view is the only acceptable and right one.

Summing up, one can say, that the author uses a variety of stylistic devices, as well as ana mixture of formal and informal language to convince his readership especially parents that it is important that more young people learn langugeslanguages in order to have success for themselves and their country.
